title: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 12: Hot Acid Phenol Method for Angiosperms
title_html: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 12: Hot Acid Phenol Method for Angiosperms

source.description:
Add
of saturated acid phenol (pH 4.3) and
of
RNA extraction buffer
to a 15 ml snap cap tube. Warm tube to
in a fume hood using a heat block.
Homogenize tissue in liquid nitrogen using a mortar and pestle.

Transfer up to
of ground tissue to a tube containing the phenol-buffer mixture and close the snap cap tube completely (second stop). Immediately mix tube by hand. Vortex until the phases mix and appear cloudy. Keep at
or
depending on whether SDS is precipitating.

source.body: Use a spatula and funnel chilled in liquid nitrogen to transfer the powdered tissue to the tube.

source.description:

for

Transfer aqueous phase to a new 15 ml tube.

Add
of chloroform:isoamyl (24:1 ratio). Close the snap cap tube completely (second stop) and mix contents immediately by hand. Then vortex until the phases mix and appear cloudy.

Centrifuge at
for
.
Transfer aqueous phase to a new 15 ml tube.

Precipitate nucleic acids by gently adding
of isopropanol to the tube followed by gentle inversion to mix the phases. Precipitate for
at

for
.
Remove the supernatant without dislodging the pellet.

Rinse the pellet with
of chilled 70 % ethanol made with RNase-free H2O.
Transfer pellet and ethanol to a new 1.5 ml tube and invert to wash.

Centrifuge at
in a microcentrifuge for
and remove the supernatant.

Spin dry the RNA pellet by successive removal of any remaining liquid following
centrifugations at maximum speed in a microcentrifuge. Repeat this process until no liquid is seen when the tube is flicked.
Allow the pellet to air dry for
to
, depending on the size of the pellet.

source.body: Avoid over-drying since this will negatively affect re-suspension in water.

source.description:
While on ice, re-suspend the pellet in
RNase-free H2O using gentle pipetting.

source.body: Ensure the pellet is completely re-suspended before proceeding to step 17.

LiCl. Precipitate the RNA overnight at

Centrifuge at
for
at
in a microcentrifuge.

Wash the pellet three times with
of chilled 70 % ethanol diluted in RNase-free H2O. Centrifuge at
.

source.body: Remove the pellet from the wall of the tube to wash the pellet more completely. Pellet will now dislodge easily and care must be taken when removing the supernatant between washes.

source.description:
Spin the pellet. Remove ethanol and dry as in step 15.
Centrifuge at
.
Dissolve pellet in RNase-free H2O on ice.

source.body: The volume of the water is dependent on the size and clarity of the pellet, as well as the viscosity of the re-suspension, but can be used as a standard starting point.

at
.
Check concentration and integrity using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer.

Purify and DNase treat up to
of RNA on a RNeasy Mini Kit spin column (pink) by Qiagen.

source.body: Follow the ‘RNA Cleanup’ protocol as published in the RNeasy Handbook, including the on-column DNase digestion with the RNase-Free DNase Set by Qiagen.

source.description:
Elute RNA twice from the column using
of
RNase-free water to a total of
.

source.body: However, if the mass of RNA applied to the column is less than , then use only to elute.

description:
Implemented by: Sarah Covshoff, Rowan Sage and Julian Hibberd
This RNA isolation method is a multi-component method involving an initial extraction by hot
acid phenol and then a purification and DNase treatment using the RNeasy Mini Kit by Qiagen.
The method described below is a modification of a method described by van Tunen et al.3.
This protocol is part of a collection of eighteen protocols used to isolate total RNA from plant tissue. (RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Collection: https://www.protocols.io/view/rna-isolation-from-plant-tissue-439gyr6)
3 van Tunen, A.J. et al. Cloning of the two chalcone flavanone isomerase genes from Petunia hybrida: coordinate, light‐
regulated and differential expression of flavonoid genes. The EMBO Journal 7, 1257‐1263 (1988).
